title: R42560
content: Mexico's prominence in the U.S. migration system has significant implications for U.S. immigration policy. The largest group of U.S. migrants are Mexicans, with about 1 in 10 Mexicans living in the United States. This bilateral migration flow between Mexico and the U.S. is the largest in the world, shaping current immigration debates and policies. The report discusses Mexico's role in the U.S. immigration system and its impact on immigration policies. It covers Mexico-U.S. migration flows, history of migration policies, demographics of Mexico-born persons in the U.S., and major issues in the immigration debate. Topics include migration control, border security, LPR visa system, temporary worker programs, and potential legalization programs for unauthorized aliens. The report examines the impact of proposed reforms on Mexicans and questions Mexico's influence on U.S. immigration policy. It also looks at efforts to reduce emigration pressures within Mexico. Migration to the U.S. includes LPRs, temporary nonimmigrants, and unauthorized aliens, with Mexicans being the largest group. Lawful permanent residents can apply for U.S. citizenship after five years. The INA sets limits and preference categories for permanent residency. The Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) establishes numerical limits and preference categories for permanent immigration, prioritizing family-based immigration. Mexicans are more likely to benefit from the family-friendly rules, with a high percentage admitted under family categories. In FY2010, 122,686 Mexicans became Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) as immediate relatives or family-sponsored immigrants. Mexicans are family-based compared to 65% of all LPRs. Nonimmigrants are foreign nationals admitted to the US for a temporary period with specific reasons. There are 24 major nonimmigrant visa categories, including B-2 tourists, E-2 treaty investors, and F-1 foreign students. Visa categories for employment include H-2A for agricultural workers, H-2B for lower-skilled workers, H-1B for professional workers, J-1 cultural exchange, E visa for traders and investors, and L visa for intra-company transferees. Temporary professional workers from Canada and Mexico can enter under NAFTA on TN visas. In FY2010, Mexico was the top sending country of temporary nonimmigrants, with a large majority entering as H-2A or H-2B low-skilled workers. Mexicans accounted for 82.9% of H-2A and H-2B visas issued in 2010. About 11.4 million unauthorized aliens were estimated to be in the US in 2010, with many entering without inspection or using fraudulent documents. In 2010, about 11.4 million unauthorized aliens were estimated to be in the US, with many entering illegally or overstaying their visas. The majority of unauthorized Mexicans made up 59% of this population. Efforts for comprehensive immigration reform have been ongoing, but no legislation has been passed in the last decade. The last decade has seen a focus on new enforcement measures at the U.S.-Mexican border and within the United States, resulting in a record number of unauthorized aliens being removed each year since 2003. Mexicans make up almost three-quarters of all removals. The regional migration system has evolved through four phases, from limited seasonal flows before World War II to increased family-based immigration since the 1990s. Large-scale permanent immigration from Mexico to the United States is a recent phenomenon, with Mexican LPR immigrants exceeding 1 million in the 1980s. Mexicans accounted for more than 15% of total LPR inflows in the 1990s. The total Mexican-born population living in the United States has increased significantly since the 1970s. The Mexico-born population in the United States saw a significant increase starting in the 1970s, with legal immigration and total population doubling each decade. By 2009, there were 11.5 million Mexico-born individuals in the US. Mexican migrants today are evenly split by gender, mostly live permanently in the US, work in non-agricultural jobs, and are spread throughout the country. This shift from low immigration levels to rapid growth since 1970 is attributed to various factors. The rapid growth of Mexican migration since 1970 is primarily driven by structural demographic, economic, and social forces. Push factors like high birth rates and limited economic opportunities in Mexico, along with pull factors like employment opportunities and family connections in the US, have influenced migration patterns. Migration outcomes also depend on policies in both countries that either encourage or discourage international migration. In the early 20th century, push and pull factors for Mexico-US migration were limited due to underdeveloped transportation and social networks. During the early 20th century, Mexican migration to the United States was influenced by limited push-pull factors. The Mexican Revolution led to additional migration, but also created opportunities within Mexico. The Great Depression caused a decline in U.S. demand for migrant workers, leading to the creation of the first U.S. guest worker program for Mexicans. Migration policy shifted in 1929 with tighter screening criteria. In 1929, tighter screening criteria for Mexican visa applicants led to a 75% reduction in LPR admissions. Many Mexicans and their U.S.-born children returned to Mexico during the Great Depression, with some being deported. Mexico discouraged emigration with laws and campaigns, resulting in net migration flowing north to south in the 1930s. Agricultural employers in the U.S. struggled to recruit Mexican workers during World War II due to limited inflows and Mexican officials opposing new emigration. During World War II, U.S. officials initiated negotiations with Mexico for the Bracero program, a bilateral guest worker program to address labor shortages. Mexican workers were guaranteed a minimum wage, health benefits, and housing. The program was suspended in 1948 but resumed in 1951 due to fears of labor shortages during the Korean War. After the war, the U.S. demanded changes that weakened the program's labor protections. The Bracero program had a lasting impact on Mexico-U.S. migration, with strong support from both governments. By the mid-1960s, it transitioned to longer-term resettlement and greater diversity in labor markets. The program issued 4.6 million visas by 1964, fostering a new generation of Mexican workers and U.S. employers. The end of the Bracero program in the mid-1960s led to increased migration pulls and pushes for Mexican workers entering the United States. Factors such as low wages, expanded low-skilled job opportunities, high fertility rates, and agricultural dislocation in Mexico contributed to this trend. Despite eligibility for H-2 temporary worker visas, the Department of Labor rejected many petitions, limiting legal pathways for Mexican workers. The 1965 amendments to the INA further impacted migration patterns. The 1965 amendments to the INA imposed numeric limits on Western Hemisphere immigration, affecting migrants from Mexico. This led to an increase in illegal migration from Mexico, with the number of unauthorized aliens apprehended growing three-fold between 1965 and 1970. The backlog of Mexican visa applicants reached roughly 300,000 by 1976, resulting in a two-and-a-half year wait for visas. By 1979, an estimated 1.7 million unauthorized aliens resided in the United States, including 1.4 million from Mexico. Congress passed the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 (IRCA) after examining the issue for 15 years, legalizing about 2.6 million people, including 2.1 million Mexican migrants. Mexican migrants continued to be a significant presence in the U.S. labor market, driven by factors such as globalization and economic disparities. Migration became a core feature of the regional labor market, with U.S. employers and Mexican workers structurally dependent on it. Congress responded to these trends by passing legislation to address the issue. After the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act (IRCA), Congress passed additional laws focusing on illegal migration, investing in border security, restricting access to welfare, and streamlining removal procedures. Spending on migration control increased significantly, reaching $17.4 billion in FY2012. Immigration reforms aimed to reduce low-skilled employment-based inflows, with laws like the Immigration Act of 1990 and the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act decreasing low-skilled LPR visas. The 1990 Immigration Act reduced low-skilled LPR visas from 29,000 to 5,000 per year and increased family-sponsored immigration limits to at least 226,000 immigrants annually, benefiting Mexicans the most. Mexico was the only country approaching the 7% limit for second preference immigrants, with a special allotment of 55,000 visas for spouses and children of LPRs who legalized through IRCA. Mexicans made up a significant portion of second preference spouses and children admitted during FY2000-FY2009. Mexico lacked a cohesive migration policy post-Bracero period, but increasing migrant deaths along the U.S.-Mexico border led to some concern in the late 1990s. In the 1990s, increasing migrant deaths along the U.S.-Mexico border and human rights abuses of Central Americans in Mexico prompted the Mexican government to reform its migration policy. The Administration of Mexican President Felipe Calderón and the Mexican Congress made significant changes to Mexico's immigration law in 2008, decriminalizing simple migration offenses and replacing imprisonment with fines and deportation for unauthorized migrants. Mexico's migration policy reforms in 2008 under President Felipe Calderón replaced imprisonment with fines and deportation for unauthorized migrants. In 2010, Mexico increased penalties for alien smuggling, focusing on abuses by public officials. Recent efforts include a new version of the GPA law to protect migrants' rights, simplify immigration laws, and promote family reunification. Mexico's migration policy reforms in 2008 under President Felipe Calderón aimed to establish family reunification and humanitarian protection as key elements of immigration policy. The law concentrates immigration enforcement authority within the federal Interior Ministry to improve migration management and reduce abuses of migrants. It guarantees access to education, justice, and healthcare services for all migrants, limits detention of unauthorized migrants to 15 working days, and gives legal status to special government "Beta Groups" assisting migrants in distress. Special procedures are established for the treatment of children and vulnerable groups. Despite U.S. enforcement efforts, Mexico-U.S. migration increased steadily in the 25 years after the Immigration Reform and Control Act (IRCA) of 1986. The Mexico-born population grew from 2.8 million in 1979 to 11.5 million in 2009, with unauthorized migrants contributing to 60% of the increase. However, Mexican migration has declined since 2006, with evidence showing more Mexicans leaving the U.S. than arriving. Factors include the U.S. recession, increased border security, and job opportunities in Mexico. Some unauthorized migrants are staying longer in the U.S. due to high border crossing costs. The decline in Mexican emigration rates to the United States is influenced by short-term factors and long-term demographic trends, such as a decrease in Mexico's fertility rate. While total emigration flows have decreased, there is an increase in emigration by middle and upper class Mexicans, particularly from northern Mexico, due to drug trafficking-related violence. A study estimated that 230,000 Mexicans were displaced by violence in December 2010, with about half moving to the United States. Some Mexicans displaced by violence have sought asylum in the United States, with ambiguous results in data reflecting increased flows. While U.S. asylum and visa data do not show a rise in Mexican inflows between FY2005 and FY2010, there is evidence of a growing number of "credible fear" claims and higher approval rates, mainly in FY2010. Additionally, some middle and upper class Mexicans may be entering through legal channels not captured in the data. A severe drought since May 2011 could also contribute to an uptick in Mexico-U.S. migration. A severe drought in Mexico since May 2011 has affected more than half of the country, leading to 200,000 people fleeing their homes. Mexico has allocated $2.5 billion for drought relief, but it is uncertain if this aid will prevent further displacement and potential international migration. The Mexico-born population in the United States made up 29% of the total foreign-born population in 2010, contributing to about 32% of total U.S. population growth since 2000. The Mexico-born population in the United States accounted for roughly 32% of total U.S. population growth since 2000. They are disproportionately likely to be in the labor force, with 25.5 million foreign-born workers representing 16.3% of the civilian labor force in 2010. Mexican migration to the United States has attracted attention due to its scale and the unique socioeconomic profile of the Mexico-born population. Mexicans in the United States have lower education levels, work in lower-skilled occupations, and have lower economic well-being. This demographic trend is influenced by high fertility among first-generation immigrants and the youth of second-generation immigrants. Mexican immigrants in the United States have lower education levels compared to other migrants and native-born individuals. They are concentrated in low-skilled industries such as construction, cleaning, food preparation, and agriculture. Mexican-born individuals have lower median incomes, higher poverty rates, less health insurance coverage, and fewer homeowners compared to other foreign-born and native-born individuals. They are also more likely to lack legal status. Mexican immigrants in the United States have a unique demographic profile compared to other foreign-born individuals. They are more likely to lack legal status, be of prime working age, lack a high school diploma, and have lower English proficiency. This profile explains why they are concentrated in lower-skilled, lower-paid occupations and have lower economic well-being indicators. Mexican migration has also expanded to new U.S. regions beyond traditional settlement areas, attracting attention to the size and character of immigration flows. States in the Southwest have the highest proportion of Mexican-born residents, while states in the South and Midwest have seen the greatest increases in their Mexico-born populations.
